column2: U.S. experts see a Russian subplot	"

column1: By Mark Hosenball and Arshad Mohammed
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON If the Russian government is behind the theft and release of embarrassing emails from the Democratic Party
column2: as U.S. officials have suggested
column3: it may reflect less a love of Donald Trump or enmity for Hillary Clinton than a desire to discredit the U.S. political system.A U.S. official who is taking part in the investigation said that intelligence collected on the hacking of Democratic National Committee (DNC) emails released by Wikileaks on Friday ""indicates beyond a reasonable doubt that it originated in Russia.""The timing on the eve of Clinton's formal nomination this week for the Nov. 8 presidential election has raised questions about whether Russia may have been trying to hurt her
column4: to help Trump
column5: her Republican rival
column6: or to fan populist sentiment against establishment politicians as it has sought to do across Europe in recent years.""Certainly Russia has become a master at manipulating information for their strategic goals: Witness the information bubble they have created for their threatening behavior in the Crimea
column8: said former CIA and National Security Agency director Michael Hayden. ""A step like this
column10: would be really upping their game.""The emails showed that DNC officials explored ways to undermine U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign against Clinton and raised questions about whether Sanders
column12: was really an atheist.The disclosures confirmed Sanders' frequent charge that the party played favorites against him and clouded a party convention Clinton hoped would signal unity

column1: Two U.S. intelligence officials
column2: speaking on condition of anonymity
column3: said the hack could be part of a broader campaign by Russian President Vladimir Putin to push back against what he thinks is an effort by the European Union and NATO
column4: a military alliance of European and North American democracies
column5: to encircle and weaken Russia.

column1: One of the officials called the fear ""a hangover"" from Putin's service in the KGB
column2: the Soviet intelligence agency.""Time and again
column3: we're seeing Russia push back at what Putin considers Russia's mortal enemies
column4: said the other official. ""He's been actively attacking the U.S.-backed rebels in Syria
column5: buzzing ships and planes in the Black Sea and the Baltic
column6: not to mention invading Ukraine and seizing Crimea. This fits the pattern.""Despite Clinton's short-lived attempt as secretary of state to ""reset"" U.S.-Russian relations after U.S. President Barack Obama took office in 2009
column7: the leaked emails could damage a candidate the Kremlin may consider hostile and benefit her opponent
column8: who has been friendlier.Putin accused Clinton of stirring up protests against his rule after a December 2011 Russian parliamentary election that was marred by allegations of fraud
column9: saying she had encouraged ""mercenary"" Kremlin foes by criticizing the vote.""She set the tone for some opposition activists
column11: they heard this signal and started active work

column1: Asked about claims that Russian intelligence had hacked the DNC to obtain the emails
column2: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange told NBC News' Richard Engel ""there is no proof of that whatsoever"" and said ""this is a diversion"" pushed by the Clinton campaign.TRUMP'S WARMER TONEAnalysts said Russia's goal may be much broader than simply meddling in the U.S. presidential election.""It's a gross oversimplification to suggest that the Russian government is all-in for Donald Trump
column3: said Andrew Weiss
column4: a Russia analyst at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace
column5: a Washington-based think tank.""It's in Russia's interest ... to portray the United States as riven with popular discontent
column6: xenophobia and high-level political corruption
column7: Weiss said. ""It fits nicely with the Kremlin's standard narrative ... that the White House rushes to criticize others without getting its own house in order.""

column1: The Russian leader may well have been encouraged by Trump's comments to The New York Times last week that with him in the White House
column2: NATO might not automatically defend the Baltic states that were once a part of the Russian-led Soviet Union.    Despite public Trump-Putin exchanges of praise
column3: Eugene Rumer
column4: a former national intelligence officer for Russia and Eurasia
column5: warned against reaching any quick conclusions about Putin's view of Trump.    ""We can say with some degree of confidence that they don't like Hillary
column6: Rumer said. ""It's less clear that they like Trump
column7: although over the years the Russians have said they prefer to deal with the Republicans - (that) they are kind of hard-line but they can do deals.""A diplomat with experience working on Russia said the Kremlin also might be betting that Clinton will win and is sending a shot across her bow.    ""Messing with her like this now puts her on notice that these are tough guys that she's got to be really careful with
column9: who spoke on condition of anonymity.A U.S. intelligence official who is reviewing the emails as part of the investigation into their origin said that those emails describing the privileges the Democratic National Committee showers on its wealthiest donors bolster the Russian narrative of an American political system rigged by the wealthy and riddled with corruption.""In addition to countering the U.S. narrative that the Russian government is a corrupt oligarchy
column10: leaking these emails fits rather conveniently with Trump's charges about a rigged system and 'crooked Hillary'
column12: who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss domestic politics. (Reporting by Mark Hosenball
column13: Arshad Mohammed and John Walcott.; Additional reporting by Jonathan Landay; Writing by Arshad Mohammed; Editing by John Walcott and Howard Goller)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-sanders-analysis-idUSKCN1060BI	Some in Sanders' army seem determined to march on without him	"
By James Oliphant and Jonathan Allen
| PHILADELPHIA

PHILADELPHIA It should have been a triumphant night for Hillary Clinton when her rival Bernie Sanders gave a rousing speech urging his supporters to vote for her in the Nov. 8 U.S. presidential election.Instead it turned into a sign of potential trouble for her White House bid. His speech on Monday to the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia urging the party to unite against Republican Donald Trump was met with some jeers when he endorsed Clinton - a sign he had lost control of his own movement.""I'm beyond disappointed
column2: California delegate Aleece Depuey
column4: said after Sanders sought to rally support for his one-time rival.  Hundreds of Sanders supporters marched through the streets on Day One of the four-day convention
column5: chanting: ""We want Bernie!"" Delegates wore ""Bernie or Bust"" buttons. Others donned Robin Hood-style hats
column6: a call to redistribute wealth from the rich to the poor. When he spoke
column7: a scuffle broke out between a Sanders supporter and a Clinton supporter in the hall. The backlash raised questions over whether - and how - Clinton could ever win over Sanders supporters. With opinion polls showing the Clinton-Trump race tightening
column8: Clinton needs Sanders' voters more than ever. Sanders
column12: 763 delegates after winning 13 million votes in the Democratic nominating contest.To many of Sanders' backers
column13: Clinton is a bridge too far. They see her as the kind of political insider
column14: backed by reams of corporate money
column15: that drove them to Sanders and his fight to rein in Wall Street and remove income inequality. Others simply do not trust her
column16: opinion polls show. In a Reuters/Ipsos poll released at the end of June
column17: some 15 percent of Sanders' backers said they would vote for Trump
column18: and 19 percent would support neither Clinton nor Trump.Sanders won the states of Colorado
column21: and New Hampshire in the run-up to the convention
column22: and nearly won Iowa - all states that could be closely contested by Trump in the general election. Clinton likely will need some portion of Sanders' support to stay competitive in those states.

column1: 'HILLARY FOR PRISON'
Clinton's campaign had hoped in Philadelphia to put the bare-knuckle primary fight behind it
column2: but Sanders' voters were enraged by Friday's embarrassing release of internal party emails by the activist group WikiLeaks showing party officials clearly favored Clinton over their candidate. Sanders supporters seemed to be everywhere
column3: often with a bigger presence than Clinton supporters
column4: a jarring sight at an event where she is due to be formally nominated as the party's presidential candidate.  At a delegate welcoming event on Sunday night
column5: shouts of ""Bernie!"" filled the air as his supporters circulated a petition to force convention organizers to hold an extended roll-call vote on the floor this week that would require each delegate to declare his or her support.Others pledged to contest Clinton's choice of Democrat Tim Kaine
column6: a U.S. senator from Virginia

column1: When at mid-day Sanders addressed more than a thousand of his delegates at the city's convention center
column2: the crowd erupted in fury when he asked them to switch their allegiance to Clinton.""Brothers and sisters
column3: he said over their jeers
column4: ""this is the real world that we live in. Trump is a bully and a demagogue."" People started shouting back: ""So is Hillary!""Sanders did not mention Clinton again. But he already had lost the attention of some of his most fervent fans.""As soon as he said back Clinton
column5: everyone stopped listening
column6: said Cindy Melchert
column7: a protester who listened to the appeal over a loudspeaker at a local park.A Michigan native
column8: Melchert said she would not vote for Clinton in November under any circumstances. For her
column9: the movement now was less about Sanders and more about showing the Democratic National Committee ""they had us and absolutely lost us.""Another protester
column11: would not have been out of place at a Trump rally
column12: sporting a T-shirt that read ""Hillary for prison.""

column1: SEEKING DECORUM
Fearing a similar scene on the convention floor would embarrass Clinton
column2: Sanders' campaign emailed delegates before Monday night's program
column3: urging them to restrain themselves.""Our credibility as a movement will be damaged by booing
column4: turning of backs
column5: walking out or other similar displays
column6: it read.Some Sanders supporters appeared willing to set aside their qualms about Clinton
column7: largely out of a desire to see Trump defeated in the election. Diana Hatsis-Neuhoff
column8: a delegate from Florida adorned with buttons backing Sanders
column9: said she planned to vote for Clinton in the general election.""Yes
column11: ""we'll hold our nose and vote.""Others felt their fellow Sanders supporters had taken the movement too far. ""We are surrounded by people who are so selfish and so self-absorbed
column13: who worked for the Sanders campaign in Philadelphia. ""Not voting for Hillary is a sure win for Donald Trump.""But that may not be enough to sway Sue Spicer from Indiana
column14: who said she had trouble imagining voting for either Clinton or Trump. ""It's hard to feel they have our best interests in mind
column15: she said. (Additional reporting by Luciana Lopez
column16: Amy Tennery and Alana Wise in Philadelphia and Chris Kahn in New York; Editing by Paul Thomasch and Howard Goller)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-kerry-idUSKCN1060PQ	Kerry says raised Democrat email hack with Russia's Lavrov	"

VIENTIANE U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said on Tuesday he raised the issue of the hacking of Democratic Party emails in a meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.Lavrov brushed off accusations that Moscow was behind the hacking ahead of the meeting.Kerry also said he would encourage the Philippines to engage in bilateral negotiations with China to resolve their dispute over rival claims in the South China Sea.
Kerry is due to travel to the Philippines later on Wednesday
column2: after a two-day visit to Laos
column3: and he will meet President Rodrigo Duterte while there.

column1: (Reporting by Lesley Wroughton and Simon Webb; Editing by Robert Birsel)"

column2: not the president

column1: By Luciana Lopez and Amy Tennery
| PHILADELPHIA

PHILADELPHIA Democrats divided over the future of their party agreed on at least one thing at their national convention in Philadelphia on Monday night: Michelle Obama was a star.The first lady gave a speech in support of a former first lady
column2: presidential hopeful Hillary Clinton
column3: and described America as ""the greatest country on earth""
column4: clashing with Republican Donald Trump's ""Make America Great Again"" slogan and bringing an arena crowd riven by a fierce fight for the nomination to its feet.""I wake up every morning in a house that was built by slaves
column5: and I watch my daughters - two beautiful
column6: intelligent
column7: black young women - playing with their dogs on the White House lawn
column10: for years has drawn praise for his oratorical skills. But Monday night belonged to her.""Don't let anyone ever tell you that this country isn't great
column11: that somehow we need to make it great again
column12: because this right now is the greatest country on earth
column13: she said.The speech triggered wild applause among delegates in the Wells Fargo Center
column14: where anger over Senator Bernie Sanders' loss in the primary elections against Clinton had taken the form of jeers during speeches earlier in the day.

column1: Some Sanders supporters had called out at some points early in Obama's speech
column2: but were shushed.Garry Mauro
column3: head of the Clinton delegation for Texas
column4: called Michelle Obama's speech ""stunningly good."" Several Twitter users said the speech brought them to tears
column5: while others marveled at its positive tone in an election year marked by blunt exchanges. ""Mrs. Obama deconstructed Trump's entire campaign without using a single pejorative word
column6: Twitter user @weddady said in a post after the speech. ""Mrs Obama's speech also disassembled Trump's entire narrative without ever mentioning his name.""

column1: Michelle Obama became the top searched speaker of the night on Google. On Twitter
column2: about 40 tweets mentioning the first lady were posted every second
column3: according to social media analytics firm Zoomph.The president lauded her performance.""Incredible speech by an incredible woman. Couldn't be more proud & our country has been blessed to have her as FLOTUS. I love you
column4: Michelle
column5: he wrote in a Twitter post
column6: using an acronym for first lady of the United States.

column1: His tweet became the most re-tweeted post of the night.Michelle Obama
column2: a lawyer who has advocated for military families and working women during her seven-and-a-half years as first lady
column3: has earned a reputation for inspirational speeches. Last week
column4: during the Republican National Convention
column5: Trump's wife Melania delivered a speech that appeared to borrow phrases from Michelle Obama's convention speech in 2008
column6: drawing accusations of plagiarism. A Trump Organization staff writer accepted responsibility for the similarities.""One can completely understand why people plagiarize Michelle Obama
column7: actress Mia Farrow said in a Twitter post after the first lady's speech. (Additional reporting by Angela Moon in New York; Writing by Richard Valdmanis; Editing by Howard Goller)"

By Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON An email leak that led to the resignation of Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz could plague her bid for re-election to Congress
column2: after a challenger said on Monday he would file a complaint alleging she had broken election rules.Political newcomer Tim Canova
column3: who is challenging Wasserman Schultz in the Aug. 30 Democratic primary for her House of Representatives seat representing Florida's 23rd Congressional District
column4: said he would file the complaint against her with the U.S. Federal Election Commission.Wasserman Schultz said on Sunday she would be stepping down as chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee after Wikileaks released more than 19
column5: 000 emails showing Democratic officials had worked to undermine U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders in his presidential primary battle with Hillary Clinton.Canova suggested that the leaked emails also showed Wasserman Schultz had used the party's resources in her congressional campaign against Canova in south Florida. Sanders has endorsed Canova in that race. ""The Wikileaks emails indicate that Debbie Wasserman Schultz used DNC resources to assist her reelection campaign in violation of federal law. According to the emails
column6: top DNC officials used party resources to monitor
column8: and impede my campaign on numerous occasions
column9: Canova said in a statement emailed to Reuters by his campaign.

column1: My campaign election lawyers are investigating these circumstances and preparing a complaint against Wasserman Schultz with the Federal Election Commission
column2: Canova said. He also repeated his call for a series of campaign debates with Wasserman Schultz.Searching for Canova's name in the cache of emails released by WikiLeaks turned up dozens of emails. One indicated Wasserman Schultz had asked staffers to take Canova's name out of a headline on a statement that was being sent out in response to Sanders's endorsement of Canova.Sanders told CNN in May that he favored Canova
column3: saying ""His views are much closer to mine than as to Wasserman Schultz's.""

column1: Canova's south Florida campaign for Congress has reflected some of the themes that Sanders used nationwide to appeal to progressives
column2: including a push for campaign finance reform.Canova has also been a critic of financial deregulation and the Federal Reserve Board under former Chairman Alan Greenspan
column3: according to his biography on the website at Nova Southeastern University
column4: where he is a professor of law and public finance.

column1: Sanders made attacks on Wall Street a central theme of his presidential campaign
column2: and called for structural reforms in the Fed.Since Sanders' endorsement
column3: Canova has almost caught up with Wasserman Schultz in fundraising. Canova has raised $2.27 million so far; Wasserman Schultz has raised $2.81 million
column4: according to the most recent Federal Election Commission filings.   There are also two Republicans seeking Wasserman Schultz's seat in Congress
column5: Martin Feigenbaum and Joe Kaufman. (Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-idUSKCN1052CJ	Trump says he would consider alliance with Russia over Islamic State	"

| WINSTON-SALEM

column1: WINSTON-SALEM
column2: N.C. Republican nominee Donald Trump said on Monday that if elected U.S. president he would weigh an alliance with Russia against Islamic State militants but rejected any suggestion Russian President Vladimir Putin might be trying to help him win.Speaking at a rally in Winston-Salem
column3: North Carolina

Trump
column2: kicking off a three-day campaign swing with his vice presidential running mate

column5: Virginia

column1: I think the ballroom and the people who own this hotel ought to be ashamed of themselves
column2: Trump said.Trump made light of Democratic disunity as party loyalists gathered in Philadelphia on Monday to anoint Clinton as their nominee this week
column3: after a week in which Republicans struggled to unite behind Trump at their convention in Cleveland.Trump waved away Republican disunity as essentially isolated pockets of resistance and made an apparent reference to U.S. Senator Ted Cruz

column5: but who knows

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN1040TO	Democrats in disarray on eve of convention to nominate Clinton	"
By John Whitesides
| PHILADELPHIA
PHILADELPHIA The head of the Democratic Party resigned on Sunday amid a furor over embarrassing leaked emails
column2: hoping to head off a growing rebellion by Bernie Sanders supporters on the eve of the convention to nominate Hillary Clinton for the White House.Lingering bitterness from the heated primary campaign between Clinton and Sanders erupted after more than 19
column3: 000 Democratic National Committee emails
column4: leaked on Friday
column5: confirmed Sanders' frequent charge that the party played favorites in the race.In a statement
column6: DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz said the best way for the party to accomplish its goal of putting Clinton in the White House was for her to step aside after the convention. Sanders had demanded earlier in the day that Wasserman Schultz resign.The furor was a blow to a party keen on projecting stability in contrast to the volatility of Republican candidate Donald Trump
column7: who was formally nominated at a raucous convention in Cleveland last week.It also overshadowed preparations in Philadelphia for Clinton's coronation as the nominee to face Trump in the Nov. 8 presidential election. She will be the first woman nominated for president by a major U.S. political party. The four-day Democratic convention will open on Monday. In some good news for Clinton
column8: The New York Times reported that businessman and former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg will endorse her in a prime-time speech on Monday
column9: saying she will be the best choice for moderate voters in 2016.The cache of emails leaked on Friday by the WikiLeaks website disclosed that DNC officials explored ways to undermine Sanders' insurgent presidential campaign

column12: was really an atheist.Sanders said Wasserman Schultz
column14: had made the right decision for the future of the Democratic Party. ""The party leadership must also always remain impartial in the presidential nominating process
column15: something which did not occur in the 2016 race

column10: an independent U.S. senator from Vermont who ran for president as a Democrat

column12: Sanders galvanized young and liberal voters with his calls to rein in Wall Street and eradicate income inequality.   But Sanders repeatedly voiced frustration with a DNC and party establishment he felt was stacked against him
column13: and the resentment from Sanders and his supporters threatened to disrupt the convention.

My Southern Baptist peeps would draw a big difference between a Jew and an atheist.""Clinton told CBS's ""60 Minutes"" in an interview that aired on Sunday that she had not read any of the emails but it was ""wrong and unacceptable"" to bring religion into the political process.

column1: SANDERS SUPPORTERS ANGRY
The emails angered many Sanders supporters who were already dismayed by Clinton's choice on Friday of low-key U.S. Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia as her vice presidential running mate. Kaine

column14: everything we believed to be true
column15: that this was completely rigged right from the beginning
column16: and that you know it was really about what they were doing everything to set it up so she would win

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-defense-budget-idUSKCN1052ED	U.S. lawmaker wants new budget requests for Iraq
column2: Afghanistan troops	"

column1: By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The chairman of the House of Representatives Armed Services Committee called on the Obama administration on Monday to ask Congress for more money to fund its plans for Iraq and Afghanistan
column2: amid expectations of a defense budget battle when lawmakers return to Washington this fall.""The administration needs to come over with a supplemental (budget request)
column3: Republican Representative Mac Thornberry said at a roundtable discussion with reporters shortly after returning from a trip to Iraq and Afghanistan.He said U.S. and allied forces were making progress in Afghanistan and in the fight against Islamic State militants in Iraq
column4: but that stiff challenges remained in both campaigns.Thornberry and other congressional Republicans have been saying President Barack Obama must formally request additional funds for the fiscal year that starts on Oct. 1 since he announced plans earlier this month to send more troops to Iraq and keep more in Afghanistan than had been expected.

column1: The request for more troops
column2: without a plan to pay for them
column3: added another wrinkle to the simmering dispute between the Republican-led Congress and the Democratic administration over spending. Obama has threatened to veto a $602 billion defense policy bill because of its use of special funds for the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq to avoid mandatory budget limits.Democrats say the Department of Defense should be subject to the same spending restrictions as non-military programs. Republicans accuse Democrats of stinting on national security in order to fund pet domestic projects.""That is holding our military hostage
column4: Thornberry said.

column1: The congressman said he had had no official numbers from the Pentagon but that he had been told it faces roughly $6 billion more in expenses than when the administration made its budget request earlier this year.He said military commanders in Afghanistan were grappling with how to handle Obama's plan to reduce the number of troops in Afghanistan to 8
column2: 448 by December 31 from about 9
column3: 800 currently.

column1: They are looking into using more contractors and whether some functions can be moved out of Afghanistan
column2: Thornberry said. Defense Secretary Ash Carter has said the Pentagon was evaluating how to proceed
column3: comparing its estimated costs with what is already in its budgets. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"
